	`life` TEXT, -- #The starting life total modifier. A plus or minus character precedes an integer. The column contains text data. Example values include: 7, 15, 2. #Values Examples: [None, -5, -1]
	`loyalty` TEXT, -- #The starting loyalty value of the card. Used only on cards with 'Planeswalker' in its types. empty means unkown. Example values: 7, 6, 3. #Values Examples: [None, 6, 3]
	`manaCost` TEXT, -- #The mana Cost column in the cards table represents the mana cost of the card wrapped in brackets for each value. 	`mcmId` TEXT, -- #The mcmId column in the cards table is a text column that contains the Magic Card Market ID of each card. 	`mcmMetaId` TEXT, -- #This column is a text column in the cards table of the card_games database. It contains the mcmMetaId of the card. 	`mtgArenaId` TEXT, -- #The mtgArenaId column in the cards table is a text column that stores the mtgArenaId of each card. The mtgArenaId is NOT USEFUL. Example values in this column include 75398, 66663, and 74112. #Values Examples: [None, 74983, 74986]
	`mtgjsonV4Id` TEXT, -- #The mtgjsonV4Id column in the cards table is a text column that stores the unique identifier of a card in the mtgjsonV4 database. 	`multiverseId` TEXT, -- #The multiverseId column in the cards table is a text column that stores the multiverse identifier of a card. 	`name` TEXT, -- #The name of the card. Cards with multiple faces, like 'Split' and 'Meld' cards are given a delimiter. Example values include 'Slaughter Pact', 'Crimson Mage', and 'Falkenrath Reaver'. #Values Examples: [Ancestor's Chosen, Angel of Mercy, Aven Cloudchaser]

	`originalText` TEXT, -- #The original Text on the cards table is the text on the card as originally printed. Example values include 2007/1/1, 2016/1/7, and 2019/12/1. #Values Examples: [First strike (This creature deals combat damage before creatures without first strike.)

	`otherFaceIds` TEXT, -- # otherFaceIds is a text column in the cards table. It contains a list of card UUID's to this card's counterparts, such as transformed or melded faces. 	`power` TEXT, -- #The power of the card in the cards table. The power of the card is a text type column. The power of the card is a commonsense evidence:

	`promoTypes` TEXT, -- # Promo Types is a text column in the cards table. It contains a list of promotional types for a card. 	`purchaseUrls` TEXT, -- #This column contains links that navigate to websites where the card can be purchased. 	`rarity` TEXT, -- #The card printing rarity. The rarity of the card printing can be one of the following: mythic, rare, common, or uncommon. #Values Examples: [uncommon, common, rare]

	`setCode` TEXT, -- #The set printing code that the card is from. For example, the set code for the card 'Goblin Electromancer' is 'GRN'. Other possible values for this column include 'PMEI' and 'M11'. #Values Examples: [10E, 2ED, 2XM]
	`side` TEXT, -- #The identifier of the card side. Used on cards with multiple faces on the same card. If this value is empty, then it means this card doesn't have multiple faces on the same card. The possible values are: e, b, a, c, d. #Values Examples: [None, a, b]

	`tcgplayerProductId` TEXT, -- #This column is a text column in the cards table of the card_games database. It contains the TCG player ProductId of each card. 	`types` TEXT, -- #This column is a list of all card types of the card, including Unâsets and gameplay variants, in the table cards of the card_games database. Example values include Artifact,Creature, Vanguard, and Phenomenon. #Values Examples: [Creature, Instant, Enchantment]
	`uuid` TEXT, -- # 'uuid is a text column in cards table. uuid is the universal unique identifier (v5) generated by MTGJSON. Each entry is unique. The example values of uuid are ebb44251-f81a-502c-8820-028c6accc192, f20e8fe9-a6e0-5d6f-8bd9-50fcb6b245f9, 028682c8-bfca-5ccb-9935-f8cd0573182d. ' #Values Examples: [00010d56-fe38-5e35-8aed-518019aa36a5, 0001e0d0-2dcd-5640-aadc-a84765cf5fc9, 0003caab-9ff5-5d1a-bc06-976dd0457f19]
	`variations` TEXT, -- #This column is called variations and is of type text. It is a list of unique identifiers for each variation of a card. CREATE TABLE `foreign_data` (
	`id` INTEGER, -- # 'This column is a unique id number identifying this row of data within the 'foreign data' table in the 'card_games' database.' #Values Examples: [1, 2, 3]
	`flavorText` TEXT, -- #The foreign flavor text of the card in the foreign data table. 	`language` TEXT, -- #The foreign language of card. This column contains text data. Example values include Chinese Traditional, Hebrew, and Russian. #Values Examples: [German, Spanish, French]
	`multiverseid` INTEGER, -- #The foreign multiverse identifier of the card. #Values Examples: [148411, 150317, 149934]
	`name` TEXT, -- #The foreign name of the card in the foreign data table. #Values Examples: [Ausgewählter der Ahnfrau, Elegido de la Antepasada, Élu de l'Ancêtre]
	`text` TEXT, -- #This column represents the foreign text ruling of the card within the context of the foreign data table. The text column is of type text. The foreign text ruling of the card is a description of the card's effect in a language other than English. The example values of this column include: 由你操控的衍生生物得+1/+1並具有警戒異能。, 將目標生物移回其擁有者手上。 其操控者失去1點生命。, Metti sul campo di battaglia due pedine creatura Spirito 1/1 bianche con volare. Guadagni 2 punti vita.. The possible values of this column are not available. #Values Examples: [Erstschlag (Diese Kreatur fügt Kampfschaden vor Kreaturen ohne Erstschlag zu.)
Wenn der Ausgewählte der Ahnfrau ins Spiel kommt, erhältst du 1 Lebenspunkt für jede Karte in deinem Friedhof dazu., Daña primero. (Esta criatura hace daño de combate antes que las criaturas sin la habilidad de dañar primero.)
Cuando el Elegido de la Antepasada entre en juego, ganas 1 vida por cada carta en tu cementerio., Initiative (Cette créature inflige des blessures de combat avant les créatures sans l'initiative.)
Quand l'Élu de l'Ancêtre arrive en jeu, vous gagnez 1 point de vie pour chaque carte dans votre cimetière.]
	`type` TEXT, -- #The foreign type of the card. Includes any supertypes and subtypes. The values in this column are text. Example values include Criatura Lendária — Zumbi Naga, Créature : zombie et gobelin, and Kreatur — Zentaur, Druide, Legende. #Values Examples: [Kreatur — Mensch, Kleriker, Criatura — Clérigo humano, Créature : humain et clerc]
	`uuid` TEXT, -- #This column is a text column named uuid in the table foreign data. It contains the unique identifier for each row in the table. Example values include 6dbb9aab-c2d9-59dd-8ea3-d954c6a29acf, 2896c920-1b81-526a-b211-a931ba0f4a54, d29d4cc6-e3ab-5986-816c-0fdf2da45c8a. #Values Examples: [5f8287b1-5bb6-5f4c-ad17-316a40d5bb0c, 57aaebc1-850c-503d-9f6e-bb8d00d8bf7c, 8ac972b5-9f6e-5cc8-91c3-b9a40a98232e]
	PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
	FOREIGN KEY (`uuid`) REFERENCES `cards`(`uuid`)

	`frameVersion` TEXT, -- #The version of the card frame style. The values of this column are '1993', '1997', '2003', '2015', 'future'. The possible values of this column are ['2015', '2003', 'future', '1993', '1997']. #Values Examples: [2003, 1993, 2015]
	`hand` TEXT, -- #The starting maximum hand size total modifier. A + or - character precedes an integer. 
#The possible values are: -4, 1, -1, -2, -3, 3, 0, 2. #Values Examples: [None, 1, 0]
	`hasAlternativeDeckLimit` INTEGER, -- #This column indicates whether the card allows a value other than 4 copies in a deck within the context of the cards table. The column is of type integer. If the card allows a value other than 4 copies in a deck, the value is 1, otherwise, the value is 0. #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`hasContentWarning` INTEGER, -- # This column indicates whether the card has sensitive content or not. The value of this column is an integer. If the card is marked by Wizards of the Coast for having sensitive content, the value of this column is 1, otherwise, it is 0. Cards with this property may have missing or degraded properties and values. #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`hasFoil` INTEGER, -- #This column indicates whether the card can be found in foil or not within the context of the cards table. The column has Foil is of type integer. The value 0 indicates that the card cannot be found in foil, while the value 1 indicates that the card can be found in foil. #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`hasNonFoil` INTEGER, -- #This column indicates whether the card can be found in non-foil. The value of this column is an integer. 0 means the card cannot be found in non-foil, and 1 means the card can be found in non-foil. #Values Examples: [1, 0]
	`isAlternative` INTEGER, -- #This column indicates whether the card is an alternate variation to an original printing. The value of this column is an integer. 0 indicates that the card is not an alternate variation, while 1 indicates that the card is an alternate variation. #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`isFullArt` INTEGER, -- # 'The column 'is Full Art' in the table 'cards' indicates whether the card has full artwork. The column is of type 'integer'. The value of the column can be either 0 or 1. 0 indicates that the card doesn't have full artwork, while 1 indicates that the card has full artwork.'<|im_sep|> #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`isOnlineOnly` INTEGER, -- #This column indicates whether the card is only available in online game variations. The values in this column are integers, where 0 indicates that the card is not only available in online game variations, and 1 indicates that the card is only available in online game variations. #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`isOversized` INTEGER, -- #This column is called is Oversized and is of type integer. It represents whether the card is oversized or not. The value 0 represents that the card is not oversized, while the value 1 represents that the card is oversized. #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`isPromo` INTEGER, -- #This column is called 'is Promotion' and it is of type 'integer'. It represents whether the card is a promotional printing. The value of 0 means the card is not a promotional printing, while the value of 1 means the card is a promotional printing. #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`isReprint` INTEGER, -- #This column indicates whether the card has been reprinted or not. The value of this column is an integer. If the value is 0, it means that the card has not been reprinted. If the value is 1, it means that the card has been reprinted. #Values Examples: [1, 0]
	`isReserved` INTEGER, -- #If the card is on the Magic: The Gathering Reserved List (opens new window), If the card is on the Magic, it will appear in The Gathering Reserved List #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`isStarter` INTEGER, -- #This column indicates whether the card is found in a starter deck such as Planeswalker/Brawl decks. The value of this column is an integer, and 0 indicates that the card is not found in a starter deck, while 1 indicates that the card is found in a starter deck. #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`isStorySpotlight` INTEGER, -- #This column is called 'is Story Spotlight' and it is of type 'integer'. It represents whether the card is a Story Spotlight card. The value of this column can be either 0 or 1. 0 means the card is not a Story Spotlight card, and 1 means the card is a Story Spotlight card. #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`isTextless` INTEGER, -- #This column is called 'is Text less' and it is of type 'integer'. It is a column in the 'cards' table. The column indicates whether the card has a text box or not. The value of 0 indicates that the card has a text box, while the value of 1 indicates that the card does not have a text box. #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`isTimeshifted` INTEGER, -- #This column is called 'is Time shifted' and is of type 'integer'. It is a column in the 'cards' table of the 'card_games' database. If the card is time shifted, a feature of certain sets where a card will have a different frameVersion. The value of this column is either 0 or 1. If the card is 'timeshifted', a feature of certain sets where a card will have a different frameVersion. #Values Examples: [0, 1]
	`keywords` TEXT, -- #This column is a list of keywords found on the card within the context of the cards table in the card_games database. The column is of type text. Example values include: ['Deathtouch,Delve', 'Flying,Myriad,Vigilance', 'Flying,Mill,Unearth']. #Values Examples: [First strike, Flying, None]
	`layout` TEXT, -- #The type of card layout. For a token card, this will be 'token'. The values of this column include 'leveler', 'vanguard', and 'scheme'. #Values Examples: [normal, aftermath, split]
	`leadershipSkills` TEXT, -- #The leadership Skills column in the cards table is a text column that contains a list of formats the card is legal to be a commander in. 	`life` TEXT, -- #The starting life total modifier. A plus or minus character precedes an integer. The column contains text data. Example values include: 7, 15, 2. #Values Examples: [None, -5, -1]
	`loyalty` TEXT, -- #The starting loyalty value of the card. Used only on cards with 'Planeswalker' in its types. empty means unkown. Example values: 7, 6, 3. #Values Examples: [None, 6, 3]
	`manaCost` TEXT, -- #The mana Cost column in the cards table represents the mana cost of the card wrapped in brackets for each value. The commonsense evidence is that manaCost is unconverted mana cost. Example values include {X}{R}{R}, {W}{W}{B}{B}{B}{G}{G}, and {5}{R}{R}. #Values Examples: [{5}{W}{W}, {4}{W}, {3}{W}]
	`mcmId` TEXT, -- #The mcmId column in the cards table is a text column that contains the Magic Card Market ID of each card. 	`mcmMetaId` TEXT, -- #This column is a text column in the cards table of the card_games database. It contains the mcmMetaId of the card. 	`mtgArenaId` TEXT, -- #The mtgArenaId column in the cards table is a text column that stores the mtgArenaId of each card. The mtgArenaId is NOT USEFUL. Example values in this column include 75398, 66663, and 74112. #Values Examples: [None, 74983, 74986]

	`originalText` TEXT, -- #The original Text on the cards table is the text on the card as originally printed. Example values include 2007/1/1, 2016/1/7, and 2019/12/1. #Values Examples: [First strike (This creature deals combat damage before creatures without first strike.)

	`setCode` TEXT, -- #The set printing code that the card is from. For example, the set code for the card 'Goblin Electromancer' is 'GRN'. Other possible values for this column include 'PMEI' and 'M11'. #Values Examples: [10E, 2ED, 2XM]
	`side` TEXT, -- #The identifier of the card side. Used on cards with multiple faces on the same card. If this value is empty, then it means this card doesn't have multiple faces on the same card. The possible values are: e, b, a, c, d. #Values Examples: [None, a, b]
	`subtypes` TEXT, -- #This column is a list of card subtypes found after em-dash within the table cards of the card_games database. Example values include Efreet,Monk, Rebel,Bird, Barbarian,Zombie. #Values Examples: [Human,Cleric, Angel, Bird,Soldier]
	`supertypes` TEXT, -- #The column 'super types' in the table 'cards' of the database 'card_games' represents a list of card supertypes found before em-dash. 	`tcgplayerProductId` TEXT, -- #This column is a text column in the cards table of the card_games database. It contains the TCG player ProductId of each card. 	`types` TEXT, -- #This column is a list of all card types of the card, including Unâsets and gameplay variants, in the table cards of the card_games database. Example values include Artifact,Creature, Vanguard, and Phenomenon. #Values Examples: [Creature, Instant, Enchantment]
	`uuid` TEXT, -- # 'uuid is a text column in cards table. uuid is the universal unique identifier (v5) generated by MTGJSON. Each entry is unique. The example values of uuid are ebb44251-f81a-502c-8820-028c6accc192, f20e8fe9-a6e0-5d6f-8bd9-50fcb6b245f9, 028682c8-bfca-5ccb-9935-f8cd0573182d. ' #Values Examples: [00010d56-fe38-5e35-8aed-518019aa36a5, 0001e0d0-2dcd-5640-aadc-a84765cf5fc9, 0003caab-9ff5-5d1a-bc06-976dd0457f19]
	`variations` TEXT, -- #This column is called variations and is of type text. It is a list of unique identifiers for each variation of a card. CREATE TABLE `foreign_data` (
	`id` INTEGER, -- # 'This column is a unique id number identifying this row of data within the 'foreign data' table in the 'card_games' database.' #Values Examples: [1, 2, 3]
	`flavorText` TEXT, -- #The foreign flavor text of the card in the foreign data table. Example values include 「この中のどこかに答えがあるはずよ！」, 魔法の刻印が、彫刻師の道具を狼狩りの武器に変えた。, and 'Quando a história se torna demasiado lúgubre, até mesmo almas boas podem escolher esquecer.' — Shalai, voz da Abundância. #Values Examples: [„Es ist der Wille aller, und meine Hand, die ihn ausführt.", "La voluntad de todos, realizada por mi mano.", « La volonté de tous passe par ma main. »]
	`language` TEXT, -- #The foreign language of card. This column contains text data. Example values include Chinese Traditional, Hebrew, and Russian. #Values Examples: [German, Spanish, French]
	`multiverseid` INTEGER, -- #The foreign multiverse identifier of the card. #Values Examples: [148411, 150317, 149934]
	`name` TEXT, -- #The foreign name of the card in the foreign data table. #Values Examples: [Ausgewählter der Ahnfrau, Elegido de la Antepasada, Élu de l'Ancêtre]
	`text` TEXT, -- #This column represents the foreign text ruling of the card within the context of the foreign data table. The text column is of type text. The foreign text ruling of the card is a description of the card's effect in a language other than English. The example values of this column include: 由你操控的衍生生物得+1/+1並具有警戒異能。, 將目標生物移回其擁有者手上。 其操控者失去1點生命。, Metti sul campo di battaglia due pedine creatura Spirito 1/1 bianche con volare. Guadagni 2 punti vita.. The possible values of this column are not available. #Values Examples: [Erstschlag (Diese Kreatur fügt Kampfschaden vor Kreaturen ohne Erstschlag zu.)
Wenn der Ausgewählte der Ahnfrau ins Spiel kommt, erhältst du 1 Lebenspunkt für jede Karte in deinem Friedhof dazu., Daña primero. (Esta criatura hace daño de combate antes que las criaturas sin la habilidad de dañar primero.)
Cuando el Elegido de la Antepasada entre en juego, ganas 1 vida por cada carta en tu cementerio., Initiative (Cette créature inflige des blessures de combat avant les créatures sans l'initiative.)
Quand l'Élu de l'Ancêtre arrive en jeu, vous gagnez 1 point de vie pour chaque carte dans votre cimetière.]
	`type` TEXT, -- #The foreign type of the card. Includes any supertypes and subtypes. The values in this column are text. Example values include Criatura Lendária — Zumbi Naga, Créature : zombie et gobelin, and Kreatur — Zentaur, Druide, Legende. #Values Examples: [Kreatur — Mensch, Kleriker, Criatura — Clérigo humano, Créature : humain et clerc]
	`uuid` TEXT, -- #This column is a text column named uuid in the table foreign data. It contains the unique identifier for each row in the table. Example values include 6dbb9aab-c2d9-59dd-8ea3-d954c6a29acf, 2896c920-1b81-526a-b211-a931ba0f4a54, d29d4cc6-e3ab-5986-816c-0fdf2da45c8a. #Values Examples: [5f8287b1-5bb6-5f4c-ad17-316a40d5bb0c, 57aaebc1-850c-503d-9f6e-bb8d00d8bf7c, 8ac972b5-9f6e-5cc8-91c3-b9a40a98232e]
	PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
	FOREIGN KEY (`uuid`) REFERENCES `cards`(`uuid`)
);
CREATE TABLE `legalities` (
	`id` INTEGER, -- #This column is a unique identifier for each legality in the legalities table. #Values Examples: [1, 2, 3]
	`format` TEXT, -- #The format column in the legalities table refers to the format of play. Each value refers to different rules to play. For example, some of the possible values are vintage, future, and modern. #Values Examples: [commander, duel, legacy]
	`status` TEXT, -- #This column represents the status of a card in the context of legalities table. The possible values for this column are legal, banned, and restricted. #Values Examples: [Legal, Banned, Restricted]
	`uuid` TEXT, -- # This column is a text column in the legalities table of the card_games database. It contains unique identifiers for each row in the table. Example values include 800243a0-1261-548a-8d9d-3fdf76ebbc66, 89afe3ee-d887-5416-8d0b-e587a3c21f4c, and 81fd1145-e08c-5691-9cd2-78346e0c041f. #Values Examples: [5f8287b1-5bb6-5f4c-ad17-316a40d5bb0c, 57aaebc1-850c-503d-9f6e-bb8d00d8bf7c, 8ac972b5-9f6e-5cc8-91c3-b9a40a98232e]
	PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
	FOREIGN KEY (`uuid`) REFERENCES `cards`(`uuid`)
);
CREATE TABLE `sets` (
	`id` INTEGER, -- # 'The id column in the sets table is a unique integer value that identifies each set.' #Values Examples: [1, 2, 3]

I'm a background process that helps keep this site clean!

I do things like

  • Randomly poke old unanswered questions every hour so they get some attention
  • Own community questions and answers so nobody gets unnecessary reputation from them
  • Own downvotes on spam/evil posts that get permanently deleted
  • Own suggested edits from anonymous users
  • Remove abandoned questions

	`team_short_name` TEXT, -- #The team short name column in the Team table refers to the short name of a team. For example, NAV, SEV, and HIB are some of the values that can be found in this column. #Values Examples: [GEN, BAC, ZUL]
	PRIMARY KEY (`id`)
);
CREATE TABLE `Team_Attributes` (
	`id` INTEGER, -- # 'The id column in the Team Attributes table is an integer type column that represents the unique id for teams.' #Values Examples: [1, 2, 3]
	`team_fifa_api_id` INTEGER, -- #The team federation international football association api id is an integer that represents the id of the team fifa api within the Team Attributes table. #Values Examples: [434, 77, 614]
	`team_api_id` INTEGER, -- #The team api id is an integer that represents the id of the team api within the context of Team Attributes table. #Values Examples: [9930, 8485, 8576]
	`date` TEXT, -- # 'The date column in the Team Attributes table represents the date when the team attribute was recorded. The date column is of type text and has the following example value: 2010-02-22 00:00:00. The possible values for the date column are: 2015-09-10 00:00:00, 2013-09-20 00:00:00, 2010-02-22 00:00:00, 2012-02-22 00:00:00, 2011-02-22 00:00:00, 2014-09-19 00:00:00.'<|im_sep|> #Values Examples: [2010-02-22 00:00:00, 2014-09-19 00:00:00, 2015-09-10 00:00:00]
	`buildUpPlaySpeed` INTEGER, -- # 'The build Up Play Speed column in the Team Attributes table represents the speed in which attacks are put together. The column is of integer type and the score which is between 1-00 to measure the team's attack speed.' #Values Examples: [60, 52, 47]
	`buildUpPlaySpeedClass` TEXT, -- #The build Up Play Speed Class column in the Team Attributes table refers to the speed class of the team's build up play. The speed class is classified into three categories: Slow, Balanced, and Fast. The Slow category includes values from 1 to 33, the Balanced category includes values from 34 to 66, and the Fast category includes values from 67 to 100. The possible values for this column are Fast, Slow, and Balanced. #Values Examples: [Balanced, Fast, Slow]
	`buildUpPlayDribbling` INTEGER, -- # 'The build Up Play Dribbling column in the Team Attributes table represents the tendency/ frequency of dribbling.' #Values Examples: [None, 48, 41]
	`buildUpPlayDribblingClass` TEXT, -- #The build Up Play Dribbling Class column in the Team Attributes table refers to the dribbling class. The value of this column can be one of the following: Lots, Little, Normal. The commonsense reasoning for the values is as follows: 
# Little: 1-33
# Normal: 34-66
# Lots: 66-100 #Values Examples: [Little, Normal, Lots]
	`buildUpPlayPassing` INTEGER, -- # 'The column 'build Up Play Passing' in table 'Team Attributes' is an integer type, which affects passing distance and support from teammates.' #Values Examples: [50, 56, 54]
	`buildUpPlayPassingClass` TEXT, -- #The build Up Play Passing Class column in the Team Attributes table refers to the passing class. The possible values for this column are Long, Short, and Mixed. The commonsense reasoning for these values is as follows: Short: 1-33, Mixed: 34-66, Long: 66-100.<|im_end|> #Values Examples: [Mixed, Long, Short]
	`buildUpPlayPositioningClass` TEXT, -- #The build Up Play Positioning Class column in the Team Attributes table refers to a team's freedom of movement in the 1st two thirds of the pitch. The column is of type text. The possible values for this column are Organised and Free Form. Organised refers to a team that has a structured build up play, while Free Form refers to a team that has a more fluid build up play. #Values Examples: [Organised, Free Form]
	`chanceCreationPassing` INTEGER, -- # 'chance Creation Passing is a column in the Team Attributes table. It is an integer column that represents the amount of risk in pass decision and run support.' #Values Examples: [60, 54, 70]
	`chanceCreationPassingClass` TEXT, -- #The chance creation passing class of Team Attributes table refers to the level of risk associated with the passing style of a team. The possible values for this column are Normal, Risky, and Safe. The commonsense reasoning behind these values is as follows: Safe: 1-33, Normal: 34-66, and Risky: 66-100. #Values Examples: [Normal, Risky, Safe]
	`chanceCreationCrossing` INTEGER, -- #The chance Creation Crossing column in the Team Attributes table represents the tendency / frequency of crosses into the box. #Values Examples: [65, 63, 70]
	`chanceCreationCrossingClass` TEXT, -- #The chance creation crossing class of Team Attributes table is the chance creation crossing class. The value of this column can be one of the following: Lots, Normal, Little. The following commonsense reasoning can be used to understand the meaning of the value: 
# Little: 1-33
# Normal: 34-66
# Lots: 66-100 #Values Examples: [Normal, Lots, Little]
	`chanceCreationShooting` INTEGER, -- #The chance Creation Shooting column in the Team Attributes table represents the tendency / frequency of shots taken. #Values Examples: [55, 64, 70]
	`chanceCreationShootingClass` TEXT, -- #The chance creation shooting class of Team Attributes table is a text column that describes the amount of chance creation shooting. The possible values of this column are 'Lots', 'Normal', and 'Little'. The commonsense reasoning behind these values is that 'Little' represents values between 1-33, 'Normal' represents values between 34-66, and 'Lots' represents values between 66-100. #Values Examples: [Normal, Lots, Little]
	`chanceCreationPositioningClass` TEXT, -- #Chance Creation Positioning Class is a text column in Team Attributes table. It represents a teams freedom of movement in the final third of the pitch. The values in this column are either Organised or Free Form. #Values Examples: [Organised, Free Form]
	`defencePressure` INTEGER, -- # 'The column 'defence Pressure' in table 'Team Attributes' is an integer type. It affects how high up the pitch the team will start pressuring.' #Values Examples: [50, 47, 60]
	`defencePressureClass` TEXT, -- #The defence pressure class of Team Attributes is a text column that represents the pressure level of the defence. The possible values of this column are Deep, Medium, and High. The commonsense reasoning behind these values is that Deep represents a pressure level of 1-33, Medium represents a pressure level of 34-66, and High represents a pressure level of 66-100. #Values Examples: [Medium, Deep, High]
	`defenceAggression` INTEGER, -- #This column is called defence Aggression and it is of type integer. It is a column in the table called Team Attributes. This column affects the teams approach to tackling the ball possessor. #Values Examples: [55, 44, 70]
	`defenceAggressionClass` TEXT, -- #The defence aggression class of Team Attributes table is the defence aggression class. The value of this column is a text type. The possible values of this column are: Contain, Double, Press. The commonsense reasoning for this column is: 
# Contain: 1-33
# Press: 34-66
# Double: 66-100 #Values Examples: [Press, Double, Contain]
	`defenceTeamWidth` INTEGER, -- # 'defence Team Width is an integer column in the Team Attributes table. It affects how much the team will shift to the ball side.' #Values Examples: [45, 54, 70]
	`defenceTeamWidthClass` TEXT, -- #The defence team width class of Team Attributes is a text column that represents the width of the defence team. The possible values of this column are 'Wide', 'Narrow', and 'Normal'. The commonsense reasoning behind these values is as follows: 
# Narrow: 1-33
# Normal: 34-66
# Wide: 66-100 #Values Examples: [Normal, Wide, Narrow]
	`defenceDefenderLineClass` TEXT, -- #The defence Defender Line Class column in the Team Attributes table affects the shape and strategy of the defence. The values in this column can be either Cover or Offside Trap. #Values Examples: [Cover, Offside Trap]
	PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
	FOREIGN KEY (`team_api_id`) REFERENCES `Team`(`team_api_id`),
	FOREIGN KEY (`team_fifa_api_id`) REFERENCES `Team`(`team_fifa_api_id`)
);

	`player_fifa_api_id` INTEGER, -- #The player federation international football association api id is an integer column in the Player Attributes table. It represents the id of the player fifa api. #Values Examples: [218353, 189615, 186170]
	`player_api_id` INTEGER, -- #The player api id is an integer that represents the id of the player api within the Player Attributes table. #Values Examples: [505942, 155782, 162549]
	`date` TEXT, -- #The date column in the Player Attributes table represents the date when the player attributes were updated. The date is represented as a text string in the format of 'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS'. For example, the date value '2013-07-05 00:00:00' represents July 5th, 2013 at midnight. #Values Examples: [2016-02-18 00:00:00, 2015-11-19 00:00:00, 2015-09-21 00:00:00]
	`overall_rating` INTEGER, -- #The overall rating of the player in the Player Attributes table is an integer between 0-100, which is calculated by FIFA. A higher overall rating means the player has a stronger overall strength. #Values Examples: [67, 62, 61]
	`potential` INTEGER, -- #The potential column in the Player Attributes table represents the potential of the player. The potential score is between 0-100 which is calculated by FIFA. Higher potential score means that the player has more potential. #Values Examples: [71, 66, 65]
	`preferred_foot` TEXT, -- #The preferred foot column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's preferred foot when attacking. The values in this column can be either right or left. #Values Examples: [right, left, None]
	`attacking_work_rate` TEXT, -- #The attacking work rate column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's attacking work rate. The attacking work rate can be one of the following values: norm, le, stoc, y, medium, high, None, low. The attacking work rate can be used to understand the player's attacking style. A high attacking work rate implies that the player is going to be in all of your attack moves. A medium attacking work rate implies that the player will select the attack actions he will join in. A low attacking work rate implies that the player will remain in his position while the team attacks. #Values Examples: [medium, high, None]
	`defensive_work_rate` TEXT, -- #The defensive_work_rate column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's defensive work rate. The value of this column can be one of the following: o, 0, es. A high defensive work rate implies that the player will remain in his position and defense while the team attacks. A medium defensive work rate implies that the player will select the defensive actions he will join in. A low defensive work rate implies that the player is going to be in all of your attack moves instead of defensing. #Values Examples: [medium, high, low]
	`crossing` INTEGER, -- # 'The crossing column in the Player Attributes table is an integer column that represents the player's crossing score. 
# The crossing score is between 0-100 which measures the tendency/frequency of crosses in the box. 
# Higher potential score means that the player performs better in crossing actions. 
# Commonsense reasoning: Cross is a long pass into the opponent's goal towards the header of sixth-yard teammate.' #Values Examples: [49, 48, 80]
	`finishing` INTEGER, -- #The finishing column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's finishing rate. The value of the finishing column is an integer between 0 and 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [44, 43, 53]
	`heading_accuracy` INTEGER, -- #The heading accuracy column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's heading accuracy. The column is of type integer and the values range from 0 to 100 which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [71, 70, 58]
	`short_passing` INTEGER, -- #The short passing column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's short passing score. The score is an integer ranging from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [61, 60, 71]
	`volleys` INTEGER, -- #The volleys column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's volley score. The score is an integer ranging from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [44, 43, 40]
	`dribbling` INTEGER, -- #The dribbling column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's dribbling score, which is an integer between 0 and 100. This score is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [51, 50, 73]
	`curve` INTEGER, -- #The curve column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's curve score, which is a score between 0-100 that is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [45, 44, 70]
	`free_kick_accuracy` INTEGER, -- #The free kick accuracy column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's free kick accuracy. The value of this column ranges from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [39, 38, 69]
	`long_passing` INTEGER, -- #The long passing column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's long passing score. The score is an integer ranging from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [64, 63, 68]
	`ball_control` INTEGER, -- #The ball control column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's ball control score, which is calculated by FIFA. The score ranges from 0 to 100. #Values Examples: [49, 48, 71]
	`acceleration` INTEGER, -- #The acceleration column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's acceleration score. The acceleration score is a value between 0 and 100 which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [60, 79, 80]
	`sprint_speed` INTEGER, -- #The sprint speed column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's sprint speed, which is calculated by FIFA and ranges from 0 to 100. #Values Examples: [64, 78, 82]
	`agility` INTEGER, -- #The agility column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's agility. The agility column is an integer type column, and the value range is 0-100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [59, 78, 79]
	`reactions` INTEGER, -- #The reactions column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's reactions score, which is a score between 0-100 that is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [47, 46, 67]
	`balance` INTEGER, -- #The balance column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's balance score. The balance score is calculated by FIFA and ranges from 0 to 100. #Values Examples: [65, 90, 87]
	`shot_power` INTEGER, -- #The shot power column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's shot power. The values in this column are integers ranging from 0 to 100, which are calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [55, 54, 71]
	`jumping` INTEGER, -- #The jumping column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's jumping score, which is an integer type. The value of the jumping score ranges from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [58, 85, 84]
	`stamina` INTEGER, -- #The stamina column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's stamina score. The score is an integer ranging from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [54, 79, 80]
	`strength` INTEGER, -- #The strength column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's strength score. The score is an integer ranging from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [76, 56, 50]
	`long_shots` INTEGER, -- #This column represents the long shots score of a player in the Player Attributes table. The score is an integer between 0 and 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [35, 34, 62]
	`aggression` INTEGER, -- #The aggression column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's aggression score. The score is an integer ranging from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [71, 63, 62]
	`interceptions` INTEGER, -- #The interceptions column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's interceptions score. The value of this column is an integer between 0 and 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [70, 41, 40]
	`positioning` INTEGER, -- #The positioning column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's positioning score, which is a integer type. The value of the positioning score ranges from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [45, 44, 60]
	`vision` INTEGER, -- #The vision column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's vision score, which is an integer value between 0 and 100. This score is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [54, 53, 66]
	`penalties` INTEGER, -- #This column represents the penalties score of a player within the context of the table Player Attributes. The penalties score is an integer value between 0 and 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [48, 47, 59]
	`marking` INTEGER, -- #The marking column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's markingscore. The marking column is an integer type column, and the value range is 0-100 which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [65, 62, 76]
	`standing_tackle` INTEGER, -- #The standing tackle column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's standing tackle score. The score is an integer ranging from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [69, 66, 63]
	`sliding_tackle` INTEGER, -- #The sliding tackle column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's sliding tackle score. The score is an integer ranging from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [69, 66, 78]
	`gk_diving` INTEGER, -- #The goalkeep diving column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's goalkeep diving score. The score is an integer ranging from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [6, 5, 14]
	`gk_handling` INTEGER, -- #The goalkeep handling column in the Player Attributes table refers to the player's goalkeep diving score. The value of this column is an integer between 0 and 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [11, 10, 7]
	`gk_kicking` INTEGER, -- #The goalkeep kicking column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's goalkeep kicking score. The score is an integer ranging from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [10, 9, 8]
	`gk_positioning` INTEGER, -- #The goalkeep positioning column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's goalkeep positioning score. The score is an integer ranging from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [8, 7, 9]
	`gk_reflexes` INTEGER, -- #The goalkeep reflexes column in the Player Attributes table represents the player's goalkeep reflexes score. The value of this column ranges from 0 to 100, which is calculated by FIFA. #Values Examples: [8, 7, 12]
	PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
	FOREIGN KEY (`player_api_id`) REFERENCES `Player`(`player_api_id`),
	FOREIGN KEY (`player_fifa_api_id`) REFERENCES `Player`(`player_fifa_api_id`)
);
CREATE TABLE `Player` (
	`id` INTEGER, -- # 'id is a unique identifier for players in the Player table.' #Values Examples: [3879, 401, 9179]
	`player_api_id` INTEGER, -- #The player api id is an integer that represents the id of the player api within the Player table. #Values Examples: [2625, 2752, 2768]
	`player_name` TEXT, -- #Player name is a text column in the Player table. It contains the name of the player. Example values include Mario Matos, James Fanchone, and Junya Tanaka. #Values Examples: [Aaron Appindangoye, Aaron Cresswell, Aaron Doran]
	`player_fifa_api_id` INTEGER, -- #The player federation international football association api id is an integer column in the Player table. It represents the id of the player fifa api. #Values Examples: [2, 6, 11]
	`birthday` TEXT, -- #The birthday of a player in the Player table. The birthday is represented as a text string. For example, the birthday of a player can be '1992-02-29 00:00:00'. The birthday of a player is used to determine the age of the player. If player A is older than player B, then A's birthday is earlier than B's. #Values Examples: [1992-02-29 00:00:00, 1989-12-15 00:00:00, 1991-05-13 00:00:00]
	`height` INTEGER, -- #The height column in the Player table represents the height of a player in centimeters. #Values Examples: [182.88, 170.18, 172.72]
	`weight` INTEGER, -- #The weight column in the Player table represents the player's weight. #Values Examples: [187, 146, 163]
	PRIMARY KEY (`id`)
);
CREATE TABLE `League` (
	`id` INTEGER, -- #The id column in the League table is an integer type column, which represents the unique id for leagues. #Values Examples: [1, 1729, 4769]
	`country_id` INTEGER, -- #The country id is a unique integer identifier for countries in the League table. #Values Examples: [1, 1729, 4769]
	`name` TEXT, -- #The name of the league in the League table. Example values include Italy Serie A, England Premier League, and Spain LIGA BBVA. #Values Examples: [Belgium Jupiler League, England Premier League, France Ligue 1]
	PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
	FOREIGN KEY (`country_id`) REFERENCES `country`(`id`)
);
CREATE TABLE `Country` (
	`id` INTEGER, -- # 'The id column in the Country table is an integer type column that represents the unique id for countries.' #Values Examples: [1, 1729, 4769]
	`name` TEXT, -- #The name column in the Country table represents the name of a country. Example values include Germany, Italy, and Scotland. #Values Examples: [Belgium, England, France]
	PRIMARY KEY (`id`)
);
CREATE TABLE `Team` (
	`id` INTEGER, -- # 'The id column in the Team table is an integer type column, which represents the unique id for teams.' #Values Examples: [31446, 1513, 31456]
	`team_api_id` INTEGER, -- #The team api id is an integer that represents the id of the team api within the Team table. #Values Examples: [1601, 1773, 1957]
	`team_fifa_api_id` INTEGER, -- #The team federation international football association api id is an integer that represents the id of the team fifa api within the Team table. #Values Examples: [673, 675, 15005]
	`team_long_name` TEXT, -- #The team long name column in the Team table refers to the long name of a team. For example, Queens Park Rangers, Hamilton Academical FC, and Sporting CP are some of the values that can be found in this column. #Values Examples: [KRC Genk, Beerschot AC, SV Zulte-Waregem]
	`team_short_name` TEXT, -- #The team short name column in the Team table refers to the short name of a team. For example, NAV, SEV, and HIB are some of the values that can be found in this column. #Values Examples: [GEN, BAC, ZUL]
	PRIMARY KEY (`id`)
);
CREATE TABLE `Team_Attributes` (
	`id` INTEGER, -- # 'The id column in the Team Attributes table is an integer type column that represents the unique id for teams.' #Values Examples: [1, 2, 3]
	`team_fifa_api_id` INTEGER, -- #The team federation international football association api id is an integer that represents the id of the team fifa api within the Team Attributes table. #Values Examples: [434, 77, 614]
	`team_api_id` INTEGER, -- #The team api id is an integer that represents the id of the team api within the context of Team Attributes table. #Values Examples: [9930, 8485, 8576]
	`date` TEXT, -- # 'The date column in the Team Attributes table represents the date when the team attribute was recorded. The date column is of type text and has the following example value: 2010-02-22 00:00:00. The possible values for the date column are: 2015-09-10 00:00:00, 2013-09-20 00:00:00, 2010-02-22 00:00:00, 2012-02-22 00:00:00, 2011-02-22 00:00:00, 2014-09-19 00:00:00.'<|im_sep|> #Values Examples: [2010-02-22 00:00:00, 2014-09-19 00:00:00, 2015-09-10 00:00:00]
	`buildUpPlaySpeed` INTEGER, -- # 'The build Up Play Speed column in the Team Attributes table represents the speed in which attacks are put together. The column is of integer type and the score which is between 1-00 to measure the team's attack speed.' #Values Examples: [60, 52, 47]
	`buildUpPlaySpeedClass` TEXT, -- #The build Up Play Speed Class column in the Team Attributes table refers to the speed class of the team's build up play. The speed class is classified into three categories: Slow, Balanced, and Fast. The Slow category includes values from 1 to 33, the Balanced category includes values from 34 to 66, and the Fast category includes values from 67 to 100. The possible values for this column are Fast, Slow, and Balanced. #Values Examples: [Balanced, Fast, Slow]
	`buildUpPlayDribbling` INTEGER, -- # 'The build Up Play Dribbling column in the Team Attributes table represents the tendency/ frequency of dribbling.' #Values Examples: [None, 48, 41]
	`buildUpPlayDribblingClass` TEXT, -- #The build Up Play Dribbling Class column in the Team Attributes table refers to the dribbling class. The value of this column can be one of the following: Lots, Little, Normal. The commonsense reasoning for the values is as follows: 
# Little: 1-33
# Normal: 34-66
# Lots: 66-100 #Values Examples: [Little, Normal, Lots]
	`buildUpPlayPassing` INTEGER, -- # 'The column 'build Up Play Passing' in table 'Team Attributes' is an integer type, which affects passing distance and support from teammates.' #Values Examples: [50, 56, 54]
	`buildUpPlayPassingClass` TEXT, -- #The build Up Play Passing Class column in the Team Attributes table refers to the passing class. The possible values for this column are Long, Short, and Mixed. The commonsense reasoning for these values is as follows: Short: 1-33, Mixed: 34-66, Long: 66-100.<|im_end|> #Values Examples: [Mixed, Long, Short]
	`buildUpPlayPositioningClass` TEXT, -- #The build Up Play Positioning Class column in the Team Attributes table refers to a team's freedom of movement in the 1st two thirds of the pitch. The column is of type text. The possible values for this column are Organised and Free Form. Organised refers to a team that has a structured build up play, while Free Form refers to a team that has a more fluid build up play. #Values Examples: [Organised, Free Form]
	`chanceCreationPassing` INTEGER, -- # 'chance Creation Passing is a column in the Team Attributes table. It is an integer column that represents the amount of risk in pass decision and run support.' #Values Examples: [60, 54, 70]
	`chanceCreationPassingClass` TEXT, -- #The chance creation passing class of Team Attributes table refers to the level of risk associated with the passing style of a team. The possible values for this column are Normal, Risky, and Safe. The commonsense reasoning behind these values is as follows: Safe: 1-33, Normal: 34-66, and Risky: 66-100. #Values Examples: [Normal, Risky, Safe]
	`chanceCreationCrossing` INTEGER, -- #The chance Creation Crossing column in the Team Attributes table represents the tendency / frequency of crosses into the box. #Values Examples: [65, 63, 70]
	`chanceCreationCrossingClass` TEXT, -- #The chance creation crossing class of Team Attributes table is the chance creation crossing class. The value of this column can be one of the following: Lots, Normal, Little. The following commonsense reasoning can be used to understand the meaning of the value: 
# Little: 1-33
# Normal: 34-66
# Lots: 66-100 #Values Examples: [Normal, Lots, Little]
	`chanceCreationShooting` INTEGER, -- #The chance Creation Shooting column in the Team Attributes table represents the tendency / frequency of shots taken. #Values Examples: [55, 64, 70]
	`chanceCreationShootingClass` TEXT, -- #The chance creation shooting class of Team Attributes table is a text column that describes the amount of chance creation shooting. The possible values of this column are 'Lots', 'Normal', and 'Little'. The commonsense reasoning behind these values is that 'Little' represents values between 1-33, 'Normal' represents values between 34-66, and 'Lots' represents values between 66-100. #Values Examples: [Normal, Lots, Little]
	`chanceCreationPositioningClass` TEXT, -- #Chance Creation Positioning Class is a text column in Team Attributes table. It represents a teams freedom of movement in the final third of the pitch. The values in this column are either Organised or Free Form. #Values Examples: [Organised, Free Form]
	`defencePressure` INTEGER, -- # 'The column 'defence Pressure' in table 'Team Attributes' is an integer type. It affects how high up the pitch the team will start pressuring.' #Values Examples: [50, 47, 60]
	`defencePressureClass` TEXT, -- #The defence pressure class of Team Attributes is a text column that represents the pressure level of the defence. The possible values of this column are Deep, Medium, and High. The commonsense reasoning behind these values is that Deep represents a pressure level of 1-33, Medium represents a pressure level of 34-66, and High represents a pressure level of 66-100. #Values Examples: [Medium, Deep, High]
	`defenceAggression` INTEGER, -- #This column is called defence Aggression and it is of type integer. It is a column in the table called Team Attributes. This column affects the teams approach to tackling the ball possessor. #Values Examples: [55, 44, 70]
	`defenceAggressionClass` TEXT, -- #The defence aggression class of Team Attributes table is the defence aggression class. The value of this column is a text type. The possible values of this column are: Contain, Double, Press. The commonsense reasoning for this column is: 
# Contain: 1-33
# Press: 34-66
# Double: 66-100 #Values Examples: [Press, Double, Contain]
	`defenceTeamWidth` INTEGER, -- # 'defence Team Width is an integer column in the Team Attributes table. It affects how much the team will shift to the ball side.' #Values Examples: [45, 54, 70]
	`defenceTeamWidthClass` TEXT, -- #The defence team width class of Team Attributes is a text column that represents the width of the defence team. The possible values of this column are 'Wide', 'Narrow', and 'Normal'. The commonsense reasoning behind these values is as follows: 
# Narrow: 1-33
# Normal: 34-66
# Wide: 66-100 #Values Examples: [Normal, Wide, Narrow]
	`defenceDefenderLineClass` TEXT, -- #The defence Defender Line Class column in the Team Attributes table affects the shape and strategy of the defence. The values in this column can be either Cover or Offside Trap. #Values Examples: [Cover, Offside Trap]
	PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
	FOREIGN KEY (`team_api_id`) REFERENCES `Team`(`team_api_id`),
	FOREIGN KEY (`team_fifa_api_id`) REFERENCES `Team`(`team_fifa_api_id`)
);
